p:
Brende associated such risks with a rising discontent with the ‘system’ at large, such that ‘the notion of ‘taking back control’—including from multilateral organizations—has gained currency in recent years among citizens and leaders alike….risks eroding the global community’s ability to properly manage the primary economic, environmental and technological risks facing the world today’ (Brende 2019). What is telling here is that the WEF’s reference to systemic discontent, lacking mention of deepening austerity and involuntary migration, masks the dispossessions and deprivations of privatization, corporate privilege and financialization. Allusion to a legitimacy crisis of multilateralism in fact reframes the shock doctrine in such a way as to enable the spectre of corporate capture to address evident global risks (Canfield et al. 2021). By 2020 this spectre materialized with the COVID-19 pandemic exposing not only a ‘broken food system’, but also profound public incapacities, further compromising multilateralism. In this moment Klaus Schwab, founder of the WEF, and co-author of The Great Reset, opined:
The connectivity between geopolitics and pandemics flows both ways. On the one hand, the chaotic end of multilateralism, a vacuum of global governance and the rise of various forms of nationalism make it more difficult to deal with the outbreak…On the other hand, the pandemic is clearly exacerbating and accelerating [prior] geopolitical trends that were already apparent before the crisis erupted (Schwab and Malleret 2020: 8, 44).
